root.name: > Print Culture and the Modern World

1.name: > The Print Revolution and Its Impact
> India and the World of Print

7.name: Copied again & again in handwritten style (tedious/manual)
Highly expensive and fragile, limited to elite society
Preserved through  Book rooms  located in temples and monasteries

3.name: First press brought by Portuguese missionaries to Goa (mid-sixteenth century)
First Tamil book (1579), Tamil translation of Catholic texts
English press grows under the East India Company (survey reports/news)
Indian newspapers begin reporting e.g., Bengal Gazette by Gangadhar Bhattacharya
Widely preserved by James Hicky for gentry

4.name: > Religious Reform and Public Debates (Early 19th Century)

18.name: Reformers publish and publicize views, newspapers
Print joined to everyday religion & new  public sphere
Muslims: printed works by Mirza Ghalib (Urdu)
Hindus: reformers launched journals like Samachar Darpan
Liberals used periodicals to spread Protestant ideas, religious issues
Religious prints used socially e.g., Youri Krishna Press, Lahore

27.name: The  New Book  included novels, lyrics, short stories, directory
New literacy forms: lyrics, fables, sermons, essays
Raja Ravi Varma produced images from epics for circulation
Cheap publications: pamphlets, books from Indian presses, bookshops

35.name: Reading increased (novels described women as heroes/heroines)
Literature aimed at raising the consciousness of women
Women highlighted spiritual experiences (Tara Bai Shinde, Pandita Ramabai)
Hindi printing focused on women s education (Kashi, 1880s)

36.name: Very cheap small books sold at crossroads & bazaars
Public libraries by 1930s across India, open to poor
Workers: Kashibaba,  Chhote aur Bade Ka Sawal , wrote against capitalism
Baba Padmanji s Satya Prakash first novel on social upliftment
Dnyanodaya: Marathi weekly for the poor (Christian missionary press)

37.name: Early records targeted Englishmen critical of Company misrule (James Hickey)
British Government controls regulation to prevent rebellion (Vernacular Press Act, 1878)
Articles stopped about British rule; free press demanded change (Indian reformers)
Nationalist newspapers inspire struggle (Kesari, Bal Gangadhar Tilak; Amrita Bazar Patrika)
WWI: Defence of India Act imposed wartime control
Mahatma Gandhi s  Young India ,  Harijan  spread ideas of non-violence
Subhash Chandra Bose s  Azad Hind Radio  opposed British censorship
Nationalist press united people, opposing imperial authority
Independence struggle continued using banned presses; India to be revived
